title: George Tilghman
text:
George Hammond Tilghman (September 14, 1896 – 1943) was a teacher who served as the <a href="headmaster">headmaster</a> at the <a href="Morristown-Beard%20School">Morristown School</a> (now Morristown-Beard School), a private <a href="University-preparatory%20school">preparatory school</a> in <a href="Morristown%2C%20New%20Jersey">Morristown, New Jersey</a>, for 13 years (1926-1939). Tilghman succeeded Arthur Pierce Butler, one of the school's three founders. During his tenure as headmaster, Tilghman guided Morristown School through a lengthy period of financial turbulence for the school marked by the <a href="Wall%20Street%20Crash%20of%201929">Stock Market crash of 1929</a> and the <a href="Great%20Depression">Great Depression</a>. He also served as head coach of the ice hockey team. Morristown-Beard School awarded Tilghman its Distinguished Alumni Award posthumously in 2010.
Early life, education, and first military service.
Tilghman was born in <a href="Johannesburg%2C%20South%20Africa">Johannesburg, South Africa</a> on September 14, 1896 to parents Henry Ashe Tilghman and Alice Tennyson Merry. His father, Henry, worked as a <a href="mining%20engineer">mining engineer</a> for <a href="Cecil%20Rhodes">Cecil Rhodes</a>. After attending the Sillig School in <a href="Vevey%2C%20Switzerland">Vevey, Switzerland</a> for five years, Tilghman completed his high school education at the <a href="Morristown-Beard%20School">Morristown School</a> (now Morristown-Beard School) in <a href="Morristown%2C%20New%20Jersey">Morristown, New Jersey</a> in 1915. He then studied at <a href="Harvard%20University">Harvard University</a> in <a href="Cambridge%2C%20Massachusetts">Cambridge, Massachusetts</a> between 1915 and 1917 and played on the varsity soccer and cross country teams. Tilghman left Harvard in April 1917 to serve as a <a href="lieutenant">lieutenant</a> in the <a href="United%20States%20Army%20Coast%20Artillery%20Corps">U.S. Army's Coast Artillery Corps</a> for two years.
Returning to Harvard in 1919, Tilghman finished his course of study and graduated with a bachelor's degree in <a href="chemistry">chemistry</a> in 1920. Later that year, he joined the faculty of the Morristown School as a chemistry teacher. While teaching full-time, Tilghman completed a master's degree in <a href="chemical%20engineering">chemical engineering</a> at <a href="Columbia%20University">Columbia University</a> in <a href="Manhattan">Manhattan</a> in 1927.
Administrative innovation.
Tilghman adopted an innovative approach to the administration and educational mission of Morristown School. He created a <a href="self-help">self-help</a> system modeled after the <a href="Kent%20School">Kent School</a> in <a href="Connecticut">Connecticut</a> under which students engaged in service experiences to improve their self-reliance. Students waited on dining room tables, made their own beds, and engaged in supervised activities to facilitate the physical maintenance and daily operations of the school. Simultaneously, Tilghman introduced <a href="curriculum">curriculum</a> advancements that integrated greater lessons in culture and business. He also reorganized the <a href="student%20government">student government</a> and established the school's first alumni magazine (The Morristown School News).
Hockey team's barnstorming tour of Europe.
In 1933, Tilghman took the Morristown School hockey team on a <a href="Barnstorm%20%28sports%29">barnstorming</a> tour of Europe during winter vacation, a novel experience for a high school team at the time. Experimenting with the tour, Tilghman sought to bolster the international exposure of his student-athletes. Morristown School's hockey team competed against club and school teams from France, Germany, and Switzerland. <a href="William%20P%C3%A8ne%20du%20Bois">William Pène du Bois</a>, who went on to earn the <a href="Newberry%20Award">Newberry Award</a> as a <a href="children%27s%20writer">children's writer</a>, starred as the team's <a href="goaltender">goaltender</a>. Du Bois' experiences in goal influenced the creation of his 1967 story "Porko von Popbutton" about a boy who accidentally ends up playing goaltender for his school hockey team.
The Morristown School hockey team embarked on their journey on the <a href="SS%20Imperator">Berengaria</a>, a massive <a href="ocean%20liner">ocean liner</a> run by the British <a href="Cunard%20Line">Cunard Line</a> that surpassed the by 24 feet. Setting out on December 16, they received a personal message of good luck from U.S. President <a href="Franklin%20D.%20Roosevelt">Franklin D. Roosevelt</a>: "The President sends them [the players] his best wishes for their success in this new field of competition, and wishes them to know of his conviction that they will live up to the best traditions of American sportsman."
During the trip, Tilghman communicated with the Morristown School by <a href="telegraph">cable</a> to share the team's accomplishments. They had a luncheon in England before returning to the U.S. on January 9, 1934 via the <a href="RMS%20Aquitania">RMS Aquitania</a>, a Cunard Line ocean liner that served in both <a href="World%20Wars">World Wars</a> as a <a href="troop%20ship">troop ship</a>. Speaking about the team's performance during the trip, Tilghman noted, "The team did very well, especially when consideration is given to the fact that it played eight games in seven days and had to take long and tiring trips. The team learned a lot of hockey and should give a good account of itself during the remainder of the season."
Hockey team's annual game at Madison Square Garden.
Tilghman also helped establish an annual holiday game between the ice hockey teams of Morristown School and Kent School. The two schools competed against each other at <a href="Madison%20Square%20Garden">Madison Square Garden</a> in <a href="New%20York%20City">New York City</a> between 1928 and 1932. They played the first of these rival games just two years after the <a href="New%20York%20Rangers">New York Rangers</a> began play in the <a href="National%20Hockey%20League">National Hockey League</a>. Starting in 1929, Morristown School and Kent School competed for the Ranger Trophy donated by Colonel <a href="John%20S.%20Hammond">John S. Hammond</a>, the first president of the Rangers. They switched the venue of their annual rivalry game to <a href="West%20Point">West Point</a>'s <a href="college%20hockey">college hockey</a> arena for the games played between 1933 and 1935.
Joint resolution against proselyting of athletes.
In 1939, Tilghman and his assistant headmaster, Theodore Mayhew, hosted a group of 10 headmasters concerned about the practice of proselyting high school athletes. The schools signed a joint resolution that emphasized four points:
The ten headmasters who signed the resolution represented Carteret Academy, the <a href="Kingsley%20School">Kingsley School</a>, <a href="Montclair%20Kimberley%20Academy">Montclair Academy</a>, Morristown School, <a href="Newark%20Academy">Newark Academy</a>, the <a href="Isidore%20Newman%20School">Newman School</a>, the <a href="Pingry%20School">Pingry School</a>, <a href="Rutgers%20Preparatory%20School">Rutgers Preparatory School</a>, Stevens-Hoboken Academy, and the <a href="Wardlaw-Hartridge">Wardlaw School</a>.
Military service during World War II.
After Tilghman retired as headmaster of Morristown School in 1939, he joined the <a href="U.S.%20Navy">U.S. Navy</a>. Tilghman received an initial <a href="Commissioned%20officer">commission</a> of <a href="Lieutenant%20commander%20%28United%20States%29">lieutenant commander</a> in 1940 and served in the <a href="color%20guard">color guard</a> for Governor <a href="Herbert%20H.%20Lehman">Herbert H. Lehman</a>'s trip to the <a href="Citizens%27%20Military%20Training%20Camp%23Plattsburgh%20camps">officer training camp</a> in <a href="Plattsburgh%20%28city%29%2C%20New%20York">Plattsburgh, New York</a>. That spring, Tilghman delivered the <a href="keynote%20address">keynote address</a> at the <a href="commencement%20ceremony">commencement ceremony</a> at Morristown School.
In 1941, Tilghman received a promotion to <a href="commander%20%28United%20States%29">commander</a>. He <a href="United%20States%20military%20deployments">deployed</a> to the <a href="Pacific%20War">Pacific Theatre</a> of <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a> two years later. While commanding a U.S. <a href="Aircraft%20carrier">Aircraft carrier</a> service unit in the <a href="Gilbert%20Islands">Gilbert Islands</a>, he died trying to get other sailors of the way of an out of control <a href="bomber">bomber</a>. The Navy posthumously awarded Tilghman the <a href="Legion%20of%20Merit">Legion of Merit</a> in 1944.
Family.
Tilghman married Ruth Slocum in the chapel at <a href="Fort%20Monroe">Fort Monroe</a> in <a href="Hampton%2C%20Virginia">Hampton, Virginia</a> on April 4, 1918. They had six children together: Henry, William, George, Jr., Richard, Anne, and Sarah. Taking after his father, Henry served as a lieutenant and then commander in the U.S. Navy. He also served as headmaster of the <a href="Gill%20St.%20Bernard%27s%20School">St. Bernard's School</a> in <a href="Gladstone%2C%20NJ">Gladstone, NJ</a> (now Gill St. Bernard's School).
